instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..
definitions.LVDS_DDC_CLK: What is LVDS_DDC_CLK? LVDS_DDC_CLK Is the DDC clock line between the graphics processor and the screen. DDC is a protocol for identifying a screen so that you know what resolution/refresh rate it wants. This is necessary for screen detection, inductor on this data line must be good and DDC voltage must be going to the LCD screen for it to work. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not recognizing screen
threads.message: Hi I was working on a water damaged board and I relplaced a few items on 5v/3v rail. It chimes now and I have CPU activity mouse flashing. but no display I’m missing J9000 ( pin 3 0v, pin 4 3.3v) <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> 0v at <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is 3.4v L9080, <RESISTOR>R9008</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R9009</RESISTOR>, L9004 all measure good so I’m guessing the lcd isn’t being “seen” I’m using a b133ew07 test screen and a “new” screen cable. if I remember the screen is from a 2010 MacBook Pro so I’m guessing this set up should work if I’m wrong let me know.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not recognizing screen
threads.message:
Test voltage at <SIGNAL>LVDS_DDC_CLK</SIGNAL>/DATA lines.
Check if both <RESISTOR>R9008</RESISTOR>/9 are good.
Be sure to test with compatible screen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not recognizing screen
threads.message:
Post voltage and diode mode on pins 2/3, 4,  6, 7, 17, 18, 21/22, with LCD connected.
Do you still get 95 ohms there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not recognizing screen
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not recognizing screen
threads.message:
Do you really need to check pins 2/3 and 21/22 by separate???
Please try to understand a schematic and do not waste time with redundant measurments.

27V at pins 21/22 is good voltage for backlight.
3.3V at pins 2/3 is also good for LCD matrix.
All is possible only if LCD is correctly recognized.

Your problem must be the 95 ohms between pins 6/7.
If this appears only when video cable is connected, then you have a problem with LCD connector, video cable, or LCD display.
As you've said LCD assembly works with other board, then the only option is bad LCD connector.

BTW, check resistance between pins 6/7 in the other board and compare values...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not recognizing screen
threads.message: Allow 10-15s (at least) after power is removed, before measuring diode, or ohm mode.

Anyway I ordered a new connector already.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not recognizing screen
threads.message:
AXG voltage only comes up under heavy graphics load.

As you have working board, compare readings between both boards.

Did you comàre diode mode to ground readings between the boards?

threads.message: Ok both boards measurements are equal in diode mode and ohms. Let’s say I was gonna attempt a pch swap what size solder balls would I use ?

threads.message: Stencil must be marked...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not recognizing screen
threads.message: Oh I’m using a bga stencil Or what I think is a bga stencil that just lines up. I will look for the Correct stencil and right down the size or just use solder paste :) thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not recognizing screen
threads.message: That BGA stencil, should have balls size marked on it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not recognizing screen
threads.message:
Balls should be 0.3mm. Ball size should indeed be marked on the stencil, you can't use a random stencil, only stencil for 6/7 series mobile chipset will line up.
If you have a decent BGA rework station you can buy pre-balled PCH and solder it lead-free. Will save your time and sanity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not recognizing screen
threads.message:
Hi, I just wanted to recap. I wanted to find the exact reason why I wasn’t getting all my signals for lvds. I’m not sure this is correct but on pin 458 of <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> I have a dead 0.00v short I removed (<RESISTOR>R2465</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R2460</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C2465</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C2466</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7781</CAPACITOR>,<CHIP>U7800</CHIP>) on this line and on <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> Pin 1 (<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_PCH_VCCADPLL</SIGNAL>)
I still have a dead short. I’m guessing it’s directly from PCH. So I’ll go ahead and replace :) thank you 2informatico and piernov
